prior_works.title: A Near-Linear Time ε-Approximation Algorithm for Geometric Bipartite Matching
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the core hierarchical partitioning and sparse cross-part coupling ideas for approximating Euclidean bipartite matching, which the dynamic algorithm adapts to maintain a sparse candidate set and cost structure incrementally.

prior_works.title: Fast Image Retrieval via Embeddings of Earth Mover Distance into Normed Spaces
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the randomized shifted-grid, multiscale decomposition of transportation cost; the new dynamic method leverages this hierarchical grid view so that updates affect only O(n^ε) local buckets while preserving a constant-factor (O(1/ε)) approximation.

prior_works.title: Earth Mover Distance over Data Streams
prior_works.authors: Alexandr Andoni, Piotr Indyk, Robert Krauthgamer, Krzysztof Onak
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how to maintain EMD/Wasserstein cost under turnstile updates via randomized multiscale sketches; the paper’s fully dynamic setting borrows this incremental, level-by-level maintenance philosophy to achieve sublinear per-update work.

prior_works.title: A Decomposition of Multidimensional Point Sets with Applications to k-Nearest-Neighbors and n-Body Potential Fields
prior_works.authors: Paul B. Callahan, S. Rao Kosaraju
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes well-separated pair decomposition as a way to sparsify all relevant pairwise interactions; the dynamic algorithm implicitly uses such multiscale sparsification to restrict candidate matching edges to a near-linear-size structure.

prior_works.title: Polynomial Time Approximation Schemes for Euclidean Traveling Salesman and Other Geometric Problems
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Popularizes quadtree dissections/portals for Euclidean optimization; the dynamic matching algorithm adopts similar randomized quadtrees to localize changes and bound the number of cross-cell edges touched per update.

prior_works.title: Deterministic Fully Dynamic Approximate Matching and Vertex Cover in O(1) Amortized Update Time
prior_works.authors: Sayan Bhattacharya, Monika Henzinger, Giuseppe F. Italiano, Danupon Nanongkai
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the blueprint of layered bucketing, lazy updates, and amortized rebalancing in dynamic matching; the new work uses analogous techniques to trade approximation (O(1/ε)) for worst-case sublinear update time O(n^ε).

prior_works.title: Near-Linear Time Approximation Algorithms for Optimal Transport via Sinkhorn
prior_works.authors: Jason Altschuler, Jonathan Weed, Philippe Rigollet
prior_works.role: Static OT baseline and comparison point
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Offers the standard near-linear-time static baseline (entropic OT) against which the dynamic algorithm is measured; its reliance on full recomputation motivates the need for sublinear per-update maintenance in the new approach.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—maintaining an O(1/ε)-approximate Euclidean bi-chromatic matching with O(n^ε) update time—sits at the confluence of multiscale geometric decomposition, EMD/Wasserstein sketching, and dynamic approximation techniques. On the geometric side, Sharathkumar and Agarwal’s near-linear-time scheme shows that Euclidean bipartite matching can be well-approximated by operating over a hierarchical spatial partition and a sparse set of cross-cell couplings. Arora’s quadtree/portal framework and Callahan–Kosaraju’s WSPD both underpin this philosophy: represent pairwise costs via a multiscale, locality-respecting structure to obtain sparsity and structural stability.

For transportation cost specifically, Indyk–Thaper’s randomized, shifted grids give a multilevel decomposition of Earth Mover’s Distance that is naturally incremental. This view is crucial for dynamic maintenance: a single point update perturbs only a logarithmic number of cells across scales. The streaming EMD work of Andoni–Indyk–Krauthgamer–Onak further demonstrates how to maintain such multiscale summaries under updates, informing the paper’s strategy of limiting work to locally affected scales while preserving global cost guarantees.

Finally, dynamic graph-approximation methods (e.g., Bhattacharya–Henzinger–Italiano–Nanongkai) contribute the algorithmic toolkit for trading approximation against update time via lazy rebuilding, bucketing, and level-wise maintenance—yielding the explicit O(n^ε) versus O(1/ε) trade-off. Together, these threads enable a fully dynamic algorithm that updates only a sparsified, multiscale transportation graph, achieving sublinear updates while delivering robust approximations and practical advantages for Wasserstein drift monitoring.
